d128_u6.prev_utt: What I would recommend is that you avoid over-the-counter cold remedies, keep him away from any friends or family who may have the flu, keep him well hydrated, um, avoid excessive dust, and avoid smoking. And at least that last one's easy because you are an ex-smoker now.
d128_u6.utterance: Well, you're right actually, I-I did quit smoking but just last week my mom took Jake for the first time. It was a Friday night, so friends were going out to celebrate a birthday.

d128_u8.utterance: Yeah. At one point in the night, though, they all went out to have a cigarette and I joined them. Since then, I've been having a couple of cigarettes at night, but never near Jake and never near his clothes or his toys. I mean, I've heard about second-hand smoking. And I-I don't want to be- expose him to it, so I've been avoiding him when I smoke.

d128_u10.prev_utt: All right, Well, first I'd just like to commend you for your honesty and that's really helpful information that you shared with me. Thank you for letting me know that you're smoking again and-and, um, I also appreciate the fact you're taking so many measures to protect your son from secondhand smoke. Can I give you some advice on how you could protect him, even the- even further?

d128_u16.prev_utt: So what I would recommend then, is to move your smoking outside completely. As a smoker, the ideal situation for a smoker in the house is if their home can be made smoke-free and the smoking is moved entirely outside, especially while he's experiencing this cold.
d128_u16.utterance: Yeah, well, you know that sounds okay. While he's sick, I might be able to smoke outside in the next couple days or so, but the thing is, usually I'm craving a cigarette the most when I have a glass of wine at the end of the day. I put Jake to bed, I open up a bottle and I pour myself a glass and I'm finally able to unwind, so, I get a craving for a cigarette, so, I'm not sure long-term I'd be able to smoke outside.

d128_u18.prev_utt: Okay, so, what I'm hearing you say is that, it sounds like a feasible short-term plan, not ideal and not comfortable because what you really enjoy is that cigarette with a glass of wine, kicking back up on the sofa and chilling out perhaps while you're watching TV. And to maintain that long-term outside smoking outside in Canadian winters where it's cold and snowy, not realistic.
d128_u18.utterance: Yeah, exactly and another thing is that sometimes in the morning, after I've had a couple of glasses of wine, I kinda feel tired or groggy or low on energy, so, even that I'm not sure is completely relaxing. Especially if I've had a cigarette the night before, I always feel so bad.

d128_u20.prev_utt: So, on the one hand I'm hearing smoking and drinking at night as a way to chill out but at the same time the next day, you're not feeling so great.

d128_u22.prev_utt: Would it be helpful to give you some information on low risk drinking guidelines?
d128_u22.utterance: Sure. I've never heard of them.

d128_u24.prev_utt: Okay. Well, Hailey, what they suggest is that women don't have more than one to two standard drinks a day or a total of nine standard drinks in a week. How does that fit for you?
d128_u24.utterance: Well, usually I'm having more than two glasses but if you're saying that's gonna minimize some risk and I guess some of the grogginess I'm feeling the next morning, then maybe I should just try and have one glass of wine in the evenings?

d128_u26.prev_utt: So, it sounds like you'd be open to reducing as a way to still enjoy the wine but perhaps alleviate the way you feel in the morning, some of the hangover effects that sounds like you're experiencing.
d128_u26.utterance: Yeah, I-I'd absolutely maybe reduce. I'll try my best to reduce, but I'm not sure about the smoking.

d128_u28.prev_utt: Okay. So, you're gonna try to reduce the drinking, not sure about the smoking, what the plan is but I think we did agree upon earlier that you would move it outside, at least while he's sick?
d128_u28.utterance: Yeah. I think that sounds okay.

d128_u30.prev_utt: That's okay. All right and, um, I guess we'll see you next week for Jake's six-month checkup. Is there anything else we could talk about that might be helpful?
d128_u30.utterance: No. I think just talking about it was helpful, you know, and I'm- I'm glad you've given me some information. Maybe just this week I can think about it a little more, you know, I-I feel pretty overwhelmed right now. There's so much to do. My days are pretty full, so, maybe I can just s-sit on it for a week.

d128_u32.prev_utt: Sure, of course, Hailey a-and again I really appreciate your openness and honesty about letting me know what's going on with, you know, the stress levels and coping and drinking. I just had a thought that there's also a good mom's group, we run out of our center. So if you'd like a referral to that or some information, I'd be happy to give you and while you think about it, if you want to, um, talk about this further with one of my colleagues, I'd be happy to make you an appointment.
d128_u32.utterance: All right. That sounds good. Thanks, Dr.

d129_u0.utterance: Dr. Morrow, I'm so relieved I'm not pregnant.

d129_u2.prev_utt: Huh, you feel like you dodged the bullet.
d129_u2.utterance: I really feel like I dodged the bullet. That was- that was probably the scariest like two days of my life.

d129_u8.utterance: Even just being here today is like minutes ticking by.

d129_u12.prev_utt: So what would have happened if you found out that you were pregnant?
d129_u12.utterance: I don't even know. I'm-I'm not ready to have a kid. I know that. I know my life is not ready for that step.

d129_u16.prev_utt: Would you be open to kind of exploring the idea of birth control and family planning?
d129_u16.utterance: Um, I don't really want to go there. I just-- that sort of stuff just weirds me out. Yeah, I take something fun and just makes it really medical.

d129_u18.prev_utt: Now, it's a discussion you don't really wanna have.

d129_u20.prev_utt: At the same time, you have some concerns about the possibility of getting pregnant.
d129_u20.utterance: Yeah, I mean I'm-I'm careful. I do what I can, but I don't wanna take anything for that.

d129_u22.prev_utt: So you found some ways to prevent pregnancy up until-- well, maybe, um, you've been pretty fortunate, and then there is also some times where you feel like, "Oh, no. What if I didn't dodge the bullet?"
d129_u22.utterance: Yeah. It's-it's scary. I mean, this is the first time I've ever had that sort of feeling of "What am I gonna do?"

d129_u24.utterance: And-and that fear was like-- yeah. Up until now, I've been good, yeah.

d129_u26.prev_utt: Okay. So, you've been able to kind of avoid any kind of consequences, and right now, you're not feeling that talking about birth control is something on your-your list.
d129_u26.utterance: Yeah. No, it- it's just- it's just weird for me. I don't- I don't like thinking about that stuff, yeah.

d129_u28.prev_utt: Sure. I totally appreciate that, and it's your decision, Olivia. You know yourself best and what fits for you. If you ever feel like you like to open up the idea of conversation about family planning or birth control, I'd love to talk to you about that another time.
d129_u28.utterance: Yeah, maybe another time. Just, I'm not ready for it. I'm not ready for that conversation right now.

d132_u1.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u1.prev_utt: Hello, again, Mr. Green. It's really nice to see you again. If you remember last week, we looked at your results here and you've got impaired glucose tolerance and you were a bit worried about type two diabetes, your blood pressure and your cholesterol are up a bit too. So today, we're meeting up to talk through some of the things that you could do for yourself that might improve the situation. And as you know, there's all sorts of things can affect your health. So can we just have a bit of a general chat, but how are you getting on?
d132_u1.utterance: Well, I suppose you're gonna give me a row and tell me it's all self-inflicted and I've got to change my ways and give up the things I enjoy.

d132_u3.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u3.prev_utt: Actually, I'm not going to do that because you're the boss. It's up to you what you want to do with you about your own health.
d132_u3.utterance: The doc said I've got to take pills for the rest of my life.

d132_u5.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u5.prev_utt: You don't seem too happy about that.
d132_u5.utterance: Well, I feel fine, but the-the doc said it could save my life.

d132_u7.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u7.prev_utt: Well, there's a lot of things you can do yourself that will improve the situation as well. So what we can do today is wee up some of those things, smoking, diet, exercise, weight, loss, all those kinds of things. So we're just gonna start and see how you feel as we go.
d132_u7.utterance: Okay, what should I do first?

d132_u9.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u9.prev_utt: Well, it's very much up to you, you're the boss of your own life. Where would you like to start?
d132_u9.utterance: Where do you think I should start?

d132_u11.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u11.prev_utt: Well, I could give you my opinion. Um, and I can give you lots of information, but I think you know the score pretty well. And I think you'd know what I would say.
d132_u11.utterance: Yeah, uh, you tell me, stop smoking and lose weight and take more exercise, wouldn't you?

d132_u13.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u13.prev_utt: Absolutely. Spot on. So stopping smoking would have a huge impact, that would have a big impact very early on. Losing weight would also have a big impact because that would help with your blood pressure, your cholesterol, and also lower your diabetes risk. So what-what'd you think about those things? Uh,
d132_u13.utterance: Uh, I loved to lose weight but it's so hard giving up the things you enjoy.

d132_u15.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u15.prev_utt: It's really tough. It's hard to know where to start, isn't it?
d132_u15.utterance: I really should do. Or shouldn't I,

d132_u17.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u17.prev_utt: How important is it for you then to lose weight?
d132_u17.utterance: Well, I'd like to see my children settled and my grandchildren growing up and I should,suppose I should be an example to them.

d132_u19.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u19.prev_utt: So can it be in there for your-your family's important to you?
d132_u19.utterance: Yes. I want to be there for them, but not a burden to them.

d132_u21.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u21.prev_utt: Yeah. So w-where do you think you can start with that?
d132_u21.utterance: Uh, I've been thinking about them a lot lately, and I want to be there for them. So have to do what I need to, to improve my health.

d132_u23.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u23.prev_utt: What's kind of the first thing you might think about doing?
d132_u23.utterance: You know, to start with, I could cut down on my drinking. Um, that's adding to my weight and to my blood pressure, isn't it?

d132_u25.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u25.prev_utt: Yeah. That would be a really good place to start, mm-hmm.
d132_u25.utterance: In fact, I think I'll try and cut out the booze altogether. My wife says I drink too much at the weekends.

d132_u27.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u27.prev_utt: So I think it should be really supportive of that then.
d132_u27.utterance: And I suppose I could cut out the crisps and pies at works.

d132_u29.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u29.prev_utt: So what would you do to make sure you didn't get hungry at work?
d132_u29.utterance: I'm gonna start having soup at lunchtime. I suppose a big bowl of soup would be far better than two pies.

d132_u31.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u31.prev_utt: Yeah. Well, a big bowl of vegetable soup. You could probably count that as one or maybe even two of your five a day. So it'd be a really good place to start. Anything else you could think about doing?
d132_u31.utterance: Well, there's one, one thing uh, I've done already, I've stopped adding salt to my food. The doc said that would help with my blood pressure.

d132_u33.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u33.prev_utt: Well, that's good. That's probably benefited you already. And the other thing you might not be aware of is that salt intake is linked to loss of calcium from our bones, which makes the bones more fragile. So reducing your salt intake will really help with that too.
d132_u33.utterance: Well, I didn't know that. Um, it's good to know. I'll tell my wife, um, she's still very fond of her salt and her mother had osteoporosis.

d132_u35.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u35.prev_utt: So well, maybe you can help her as well and that would be good. Well, I think you've got off to a really great start, Mr. Green. You're very well aware of what you-you need to do, and you've obviously thought about it and got some good plans in place. So you're going to reduce your-your alcohol intake, you've already started by reducing your salt intake. Um, perhaps when we meet up next time we could talk a little bit about smoking and exercise as well, when you're ready for that. So how do you feel now?
d132_u35.utterance: I feel if I go ahead and do as I say with cutting down on the pies, the crisps, um, and cutting out the booze, I feel I'm making a start but let's take it a step at a time and see how it goes. But, uh, the next day when we look at it, the figures might be a lot better.

d132_u37.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u37.prev_utt: That's great. So should we meet up at the same time next week then?

d132_u39.topic: diet; reducing alcohol consumption; diabetes management
d132_u39.prev_utt: That's great. All the very best then.

book_d1.utterance: I know I don't eat enough fruit. I could probably do a better job in that area.

book_d3.utterance: I'm looking for a new type of exercise that is more relaxing and easier on my joints. I've been under a lot of stress lately. Do you know of any?

book_d4.utterance: My blood sugars have been a little higher than normal lately.

book_d5.prev_utt: You'd like to get your blood sugars down. What concerns you most about high blood sugars?

book_d6.utterance: I know I drink too much soda, but I hate the taste of diet drinks. I should try to drink more water, but it's really bland and boring. I need ideas for making water taste better.

book_d7.utterance: I like your idea of adding more vegetables to the meals I already make. That shouldn't be too hard.

book_d8.prev_utt: What ideas do you have for adding vegetables to the meals you already make?
book_d8.utterance: I'm still not so sure about it. Maybe just try to cook dishes with vegetables.

book_d9.utterance: I think I could fit in walks on the weekends, possibly one on Saturday and one on Sunday.

book_d10.prev_utt: Now that I've explained the different changes that clients with high blood pressure often make, which one, if any, sounds most appealing to you right now?
book_d10.utterance: I've been wanting to start exercising again, so I think I'd like to start with that one.

book_d11.utterance: I know I'm supposed to work out all the time, but it's too hard to stick with it, so I don't even know why I bother.

book_d12.prev_utt: You've noticed that it's challenging to maintain a regular exercise routine with your busy schedule, and you're aware that exercising has many benefits. You'd like to experience those benefits again.
book_d12.utterance: Yes. I know that when I was younger and I was running regularly, I felt like a million bucks. I had more energy and I just felt better about myself in general.

book_d13.utterance: I'm tired of feeling so tired all the time. So I'm really hoping you can help me change my diet. I'm willing to do whatever it takes. Just give me a plan and I'll do it!

book_d14.prev_utt: You're motivated to make a change that improves your energy. What else is important to you about making this change?
book_d14.utterance: I just don't think I'm getting the nutrition I need since I eat out all the time. I want to be healthier.

book_d15.prev_utt: Your health is important to you. How would your life be different if you did decide to change up your diet a bit?
book_d15.utterance: I'd probably have to start cooking more. I'm a pretty decent cook, I've just gotten lazy lately and it has been easier to eat out. But the foods I'm eating at restaurants are not the healthiest and I always leave restaurants feeling sluggish and bloated.

book_d16.prev_utt: What ideas do you have for quick easy snacks to eat right after your practices?
book_d16.utterance: I have no idea. What are athletes supposed to eat after workouts?

book_d17.prev_utt: Some of my clients have found it easiest to keep nonperishable foods in their lockers like granola bars or trail mix. That way they can get started on refueling their muscles right after practice. What are your thoughts on that idea?
book_d17.utterance: Sure, I guess I could try that.

book_d18.prev_utt: It sounds like you're somewhat interested, but I also get the feeling that you have some hesitations.
book_d18.utterance: Yeah, it could work, but I'm sure the guys will give me a hard time about it in the locker room.

book_d19.prev_utt: It sounds like loading up your locker with food isn't exactly cool.
book_d19.utterance: No. And while they're making fun of me, they'll be asking me for some too.

book_d20.prev_utt: Yes, and I bet you don't want to be giving away all of your food. Those are some legitimate concerns. You'd like to increase your performance and you recognize that eating after practice might help. You also have some barriers to making it happen. What ideas do you have?
book_d20.utterance: I could keep food in my car.

book_d21.utterance: Giving up my energy drinks is going to be hard. I'll probably be dragging for a few days. But I quit smoking a few years ago and nothing can be as hard as that was.

book_d22.utterance: I'm just here because my doctor told me he wanted me to try changing my diet before he puts me on those drugs to lower my cholesterol.

book_d23.prev_utt: OK, so you're here because your doctor referred you for help lowering your cholesterol through diet and exercise. How do you feel about being here?
book_d23.utterance: I don't know. He doesn't know that I already tried making changes a year ago when I was with my last doctor and it was impossible.

book_d24.prev_utt: You tried making changes on your own; you obviously care about your health. Tell me more about that.
book_d24.utterance: Yeah, it's not like I want a heart attack or anything. I just don't have time to eat all perfect, so I wish he'd just give me those drugs already.

book_d25.prev_utt: You're aware of the risks of high cholesterol and having a heart attack is one risk that concerns you.
book_d25.utterance: Yeah, I would like to stick around a little longer. I'm good at popping pills. It's the whole cooking thing that gets me. Plus, I like food, and I like to eat and you're just going to tell me to stop eating, or something.

book_d26.prev_utt: We have about 30 minutes to spend together today and I'm wondering how I can best help you.
book_d26.utterance: You can help me by telling my doctor just to give me those pills!

book_d27.prev_utt: I'd be happy to talk to your doctor about that. How else can I help?
book_d27.utterance: I don't know. I eat out a lot, and I can't really cook all that great, so maybe just tell me what foods I can order, or something.

book_d28.prev_utt: What's most feasible for you right now is to maybe make a few changes in the foods you order when you eat out. You've come up with a change that feels doable to you. Tell me more about the foods you like to order at a restaurant. What are your favorites?
book_d28.utterance: I like a good burger and French fries. I also get burritos from the Mexican restaurant near my work. Now and then I hit up a sandwich shop, and I get pizza and beer with the guys on Friday nights. Oh, and I just started going to this new BBQ place a few blocks from my apartment where the ribs are something else! I just start salivating when I think about them.

book_d29.prev_utt: You have many restaurant favorites. Before we start talking about finding a few small changes in what you order to lower your cholesterol, can we talk for a moment about your health concerns?

book_d30.prev_utt: You mentioned earlier that you don't want to have a heart attack. What else motivates you to make choices that support your health right now?
book_d30.utterance: I have this new girlfriend who's pretty special. We really have a good time together. And things are just getting good, so I don't want to die on her.

book_d31.prev_utt: There's someone special in your life who might miss you.
book_d31.utterance: Yeah, she wanted to come today, but had to be somewhere else. When I told her about this cholesterol stuff, she was like, You're stubborn as hell; I don't know how that dietitian is going to get you to do anything with your diet. She knows me pretty well, doesn't she?

book_d32.prev_utt: It's nice when the people we care about get us. I'm not really interested in talking you into doing anything you don't want to do. It's your health and your body, and you get to decide how you want to treat it. I'm just here if you want help.
book_d32.utterance: Yeah, it can't hurt to make a few changes, as long as I still get to eat my ribs.

book_d33.prev_utt: Yes, let's be sure to keep those as part of your diet. They sound pretty important to you.
book_d33.utterance: They'd be important to you too if you had tried them.

book_d34.prev_utt: I'll have to be sure and do that. What else motivates you to want to treat your body right?
book_d34.utterance: I've seen some close friends go through the wringer lately in terms of their health. I don't want the last few decades to be a miserable existence. I want to get out and do things when I retire.

book_d35.prev_utt: You'd like to stay active in your older years, and you believe taking care of yourself now might pay off later.
book_d35.utterance: Yes, plus these doctors' visits cost a fortune and that's one fortune I won't have as I get older.

book_d36.prev_utt: Cost of medical bills if your health declines also motivates you to stay healthy.
book_d36.utterance: Yeah, I have a hard enough time as it is making my bills each month; I don't need medical debt.

book_d37.prev_utt: Thank you for explaining what motivates you to change. You mentioned that being healthy and active for your girlfriend are important, as well as cost. What else?
book_d37.utterance: Can't think of anything. I lead a pretty simple life.

book_d38.prev_utt: You care about getting your blood sugars into a nor- mal range and mentioned a desire to cut back on the amount of crackers you eat.
book_d38.utterance: Yes, I've been working at this for 15 years, but it seems like my diabetes has changed recently. So I can't keep doing the same thing. I need to change the way I do things.

book_d39.prev_utt: How do you think you'll go about making this change?
book_d39.utterance: You know, that's where I'm stuck. I've been at this for so long, I'm not sure where to go from here.

book_d40.prev_utt: You mentioned earlier that it's important for you to be able to be a part of your grandkids' lives.
book_d40.utterance: I just want to be an active part of their lives, not just a grandfather who sits back and watches everything.

book_d41.prev_utt: You want to be in the game. What have you already heard about nutrition for dialysis?
book_d41.utterance: Well, I remember my doctor saying I'm going to need to eat more protein, but I just hate those dialysis protein drinks.

book_d42.prev_utt: You're right, increasing your protein will help to improve your overall health while on dialysis. There are many ways to increase your protein other than drinking supplements. Are you interested in hearing them?

book_d43.prev_utt: Some dialysis patients eat more eggs, whereas others prefer beef, poultry, pork, or fish. In fact, I have a handout on high-protein meal ideas for individuals on dialysis. Would this be helpful for you?
book_d43.utterance: Yes. That would be great. My wife will appreciate it.

book_d44.utterance: I just need to drink those diet shakes for breakfast and lunch. Then, no matter what I have for dinner, I'll still lose weight. I've already gone to the store and bought a batch of them. They're really good.

book_d45.prev_utt: You're excited to start making some positive changes in your eating patterns. What concerns do you have about how this might go?
book_d45.utterance: None, really. I've tried diets like this before and I seem to lose a lot of weight in a short amount of time. So it does work.

book_d46.prev_utt: You've noticed in the short term that you lose weight when sticking to a diet with meal replacement shakes. What was it about this eating plan that made you stop?
book_d46.utterance: I think I just wasn't motivated enough last time. I'm newly single and so I really need to lose this weight since I need to get out there and start dating again.

book_d47.prev_utt: You're anxious to start seeing some results. However, I have a concern about the approach you've chosen. Can I share my concern with you?

book_d48.prev_utt: In your efforts to switch over to a vegetarian diet, you mentioned a desire to add more protein-rich foods to your dinner meals. We've discussed a few ideas. Which ideas appeal to you the most?
book_d48.utterance: I like the idea of adding beans to some of the meals I already make. I'm also interested in trying out some of the premade items you mentioned like vegetarian burgers and sausage. I don't have a lot of time to spend in the kitchen in the evenings and those ideas are the easiest.

book_d49.prev_utt: Given your time constraints and taste preferences, adding beans and frozen items are a good place to start. As you begin making this new change, is it helpful for you to have a goal in mind, in terms of a certain number of days per week to add these foods to your dinner meals?
book_d49.utterance: Yes, I do better when I know exactly what I'm aiming for.

book_d50.prev_utt: What sounds like a reasonable goal to start with?
book_d50.utterance: I should probably start small, like two days a week.

book_d51.prev_utt: OK, two days a week. What can I provide at this point to help you reach your goal?

book_d52.prev_utt: What ideas do you have for specific meals that include the foods we've discussed?
book_d52.utterance: I know I can make beans and rice, but I'm sure I can come up with other ideas.

book_d53.prev_utt: I have some vegetarian recipes here that include beans. Would you be interested in looking at those for some ideas?

book_d54.prev_utt: Here they are. Which, if any, of these sound appealing?
book_d54.utterance: I like that corn and bean salad recipe. I'm going to try that one this week.

book_d55.prev_utt: You sound ready to make this change. What other pieces of this protein-boost can I help you with?
book_d55.utterance: Nothing. I think I can do this. I just need to make sure I've got the items I need on my grocery list. I get lazy with shopping lists sometimes, so I will try to be better about that.

book_d56.prev_utt: You've mentioned an interest in trying to include an afternoon snack each workday. How confident are you on a scale from 0 to 10 that you can make this change, with 0 being not at all confident and 10 being very confident?

book_d57.prev_utt: Tell me about your answer. Why not an 8 or a 6?
book_d57.utterance: Well, I'm hungry in the afternoon, so I'm sure I'll remember to eat. I'm just not sure I'll remember to pack my afternoon snack, so I may end up eating something out of the vending machine instead. I'm not sure I'll feel good about that.

book_d58.prev_utt: So you're fairly confident that you'll be able to eat an afternoon snack most days, but you're not as confident that you'll be eating a healthy snack.

book_d59.prev_utt: What do you think will get in the way of packing and bringing that snack with you to work?
book_d59.utterance: I think it's just a memory issue. I'm afraid I'll forget.

book_d60.utterance: I could probably put a reminder on my phone that goes off 10 minutes before I leave the house.

book_d61.prev_utt: What concerns, if any, do you have about your blood sugar being high?
book_d61.utterance: Well, I know it's not good.

book_d62.prev_utt: You've heard there are some health consequences to high blood sugar.
book_d62.utterance: Yes, like I remember my mom had terrible trouble with pain in her feet. Oh, it was awful.

book_d63.utterance: I can't even keep chocolate chip cookies in the house.

book_d64.prev_utt: You feel out of control around them.
book_d64.utterance: Yes, especially when they are fresh out of the oven. I'll binge.

book_d65.prev_utt: You eat more than you'd like to and feel guilty afterward.

book_d66.prev_utt: You used the term binge. Tell me more about how you qualify a binge.
book_d66.utterance: For cookies, I think four is too many.

book_d67.prev_utt: What are your plans for feeding your infant after she's born?
book_d67.utterance: I haven't decided yet. I'll probably bottle feed since it's easiest.

book_d68.prev_utt: At this point, bottle feeding seems like an easier choice. What is it about bottle feeding that seems like the easiest choice?
book_d68.utterance: Well, that way I can sort of pass the baby around to my mom and other people in my family for feedings. Then the responsibility won't always be on me.

book_d69.prev_utt: You're hoping others will help out, and bottle feeding seems like the best way others might be able to help you.
book_d69.utterance: Yes. That way my boyfriend can get up in the middle of the night to feed her and I can keep sleeping.

book_d70.prev_utt: Bottle feeding in the middle of the night sounds easier to you. I also heard you say that you haven't completely decided yet. What is it about breastfeeding that has you on the fence?
book_d70.utterance: I know that it will be a hassle to actually prepare the bottle in the middle of the night. Plus, I don't want to buy formula all the time.

book_d71.prev_utt: Fumbling around in the dark with bottles and formula isn't your idea of a good time. At this point, how interested are you in breastfeeding on a scale from 0 to 10, with 10 being very interested and 0 being not at all interested?
book_d71.utterance: I'd say that I'm at about a 6.

book_d72.prev_utt: You're on the fence about this. Tell me why you chose a 6.
book_d72.utterance: Well, I'm worried I'm going to want to go out with my friends or something and not feel like I can leave my baby if I breastfeed. But my friends were telling me that breastfeeding would help me lose the baby weight.

book_d73.prev_utt: You're feeling conflicted. On one hand, you want to be able to continue to do the things you enjoy and on the other hand the benefit of weight loss following your pregnancy is a big motivator for you to breastfeed.
book_d73.utterance: Yeah, and I'm sure you're gonna tell me about how it's good for my baby too.

book_d74.prev_utt: You already know about some of the health benefits for your baby. What have you heard?
book_d74.utterance: I don't really know the details, I've just heard it's better for the baby.

book_d75.prev_utt: Would you like to hear more about that?
book_d75.utterance: Not really. I don't need to know the details.

book_d76.prev_utt: All right. Let's see if I got it all. You're on the fence about breastfeeding, with your biggest concern being sharing the load of the feeding and having the flexibility to go out with your friends. You mentioned weight loss, your baby's health, saving money, and ease of feeding in the middle of the night as aspects that are important to you. You've also said you'd really like help from friends and family. Perhaps you're wondering if you breastfed, how they might help take care of the baby so that you could get more sleep.
book_d76.utterance: Lord knows I'm going to need some help!

book_d77.prev_utt: If you were to breastfeed, what are some ways your friends and family could help you?
book_d77.utterance: I'm going to need babysitters so I can nap. I'm sure there will be diapers that will need changing!

book_d78.prev_utt: Right, so just being present during the day would be helpful. Would you be interested in hearing other ways your friends and family could help if you did decide to breastfeed?

book_d79.utterance: I know I don't eat enough vegetables. When my sister was on a Kito diet she was eating vegetables all the time.

book_d80.prev_utt: You saw your sister succeeding and you think it would work for you too.

book_d81.prev_utt: If you did decide to add more vegetables to your diet, how would you go about it?
book_d81.utterance: I don't know. I've never done much with them before.

book_d82.prev_utt: You're a little unsure about how to prepare them and incorporate them into your meals and snacks.
book_d82.utterance: My sister has me over for dinner sometimes. One time she made a stir fry that I really liked. I guess I could ask her how she does it.

book_d83.utterance: Thinking about what and when to eat is a constant stress and some days I'm just too tired.

book_d84.prev_utt: You've been through a lot, and some days it wears you down; you're here today because you're not ready to give up.
book_d84.utterance: I can't give up. I have to do this.

book_d85.utterance: I don't even know what I'm supposed to be doing here.

book_d86.prev_utt: You're unsure about your purpose here today.
book_d86.utterance: No, I know I have to get my cholesterol down. I don't know what you're going to do about it.

book_d87.prev_utt: You're used to doing things on your own.
book_d87.utterance: Well if I don't, no one else will.

book_d88.utterance: I was just so much better at this when I did it before.

book_d89.utterance: I could get up in the morning and exercise first thing.

book_d90.prev_utt: You were able to make exercise a top priority.
book_d90.utterance: Well, I just knew it would make me feel better, and it really did. My therapist used to beg me to exercise. I felt like it worked better than my meds. I even slept better.

book_d91.prev_utt: Exercising keeps your energy levels up and helps to subdue the depression, keeping you in a healthier place.
book_d91.utterance: I think that I can get up in the morning and walk around the outdoor mall near my house. It's not that big of a deal. I just need to think about how good it's going to make me feel.

book_d92.utterance: All my sisters have diabetes and my mother too.

book_d93.prev_utt: And it worries you that you're next.
book_d93.utterance: Yes, I'm scared that if I don't change what I'm doing now, that I'm going to get it too.

book_d94.prev_utt: You see that there are some things you can do that might reduce your chances of developing diabetes.
book_d94.utterance: I do. I think I need to quit drinking soda, for one. I go through a 12-pack a week. I think that's where I need to start.

book_d95.prev_utt: Once you see your goal, you don't back down.
book_d95.utterance: Yes, I'm a goal-driven person. I've always been that way.

book_d96.prev_utt: How do you feel about being physically active?
book_d96.utterance: I know I need to exercise more. I was going for walks in the afternoon but it has been so cold lately, so I've stopped.

book_d97.prev_utt: You'd like to figure out ways to be active that aren't influenced by the weather. What other reasons, if any, caused you to stop?
book_d97.utterance: Honestly, it felt like a chore. I would just rather not.

book_d98.prev_utt: It was something you made yourself do but you weren't getting any enjoyment out of it. And now that the weather is better, you're finding it hard to get going again.
book_d98.utterance: Yes, but I don't know what else to do. I can't afford to join a gym.

book_d99.prev_utt: Money is another factor. Tell me about a time when you enjoyed being physically active, if that's ever been the case?
book_d99.utterance: I used to be very active when I was younger. I'd walk for an hour in the morning just to get outside and breathe in the fresh air.

book_d100.prev_utt: It sounds like you used to really enjoy your walks. What changed for you? Why does it feel like a chore now?
book_d100.utterance: I'm not comfortable like I used to be. I was thin then.

book_d101.prev_utt: Exercising felt good because you weren't self-conscious about your body. What about going for a walk makes you feel self-conscious now?
book_d101.utterance: I just feel like everyone's looking at me and thinking about how much weight I've gained. I know I shouldn't care about what they think, but it just bothers me.

book_d102.prev_utt: You've stopped doing something that you used to really enjoy because you're afraid of what people may or may not be thinking about you. What do you think about that?
book_d102.utterance: It sounds stupid. I really don't even run into people I know when I go on a walk.

book_d103.prev_utt: It doesn't sound logical to you. I wonder if you had something else to think about or focus on while walking you wouldn't worry about what other people are think- ing. When you used to walk, what did you like to think about?
book_d103.utterance: I just liked feeling strong. I would go out in the morning when the air is crisp and push myself to do more than I did before.

book_d104.prev_utt: You felt powerful during your walks, like you had accomplished something when you were done. I bet doing it in the morning set you up for a good day too.
book_d104.utterance: Yeah, it usually would. I'm far more organized when I get up in the morning. Plus I sleep better when I have a routine and make myself get up.

book_d105.prev_utt: Working out was never really about how you looked, but more about how it made you feel. You felt powerful and accomplished; you got a jump on the day and felt more organized; plus, you slept better, giving you more energy the next day. Physical activity did a lot of positive things for you, but now the thought that people might think less of you is getting in the way of you feeling good about yourself. What do you think?
book_d105.utterance: I guess so. I just don't know how to get over that hurdle. It gets in my way every time. I have really good intentions and then each time I try to do it, it gets harder and harder.

book_d106.prev_utt: You're looking for ways to overcome those hurdles. I have some ideas if you'd like to hear them.

book_d107.prev_utt: People tend to feel inspired to exercise when they focus on the way being active makes them feel. You might find you enjoy it more when you are more focused on how you feel instead of los- ing weight. Some things to notice might be your breathing, how your muscles move, and how your energy level increases. Just like before, you would smell the crisp air and enjoy your surroundings in the morning. What do you think of this information?
book_d107.utterance: I like that. I think I have been too wrapped up in my head that I'm not enjoying the process. It might even be fun to call up one of my girlfriends and ask her to go with me.

book_d108.prev_utt: Some of my clients have found it helpful to set up a reward system when getting started with a new activity plan. Would you be interested in hearing more about this strategy?

book_d109.prev_utt: There are many ways to do it, and you can decide what might work best for you. One way is to set a weekly goal such as going for a walk three days a week. And then for each week you are successful in reaching that goal, you treat yourself to an inexpensive reward, such as a magazine in the grocery store checkout line or downloading a new song to listen to. Others prefer setting up rewards based on total minutes or steps per week or per month. What do you think of this approach?
book_d109.utterance: I like that. I love going to the movies, so I think I'll take myself to the movies at the end of the month if I've met my monthly goal. Maybe I could set a monthly goal of going for a walk 12 times.

book_d110.prev_utt: It says here that you are physically active once a week, and you've written in the margin “if I'm lucky.” What do you mean by “if I'm lucky”?
book_d110.utterance: Well, I have a lot going on. If everything comes together I'll be able to steal away to the gym for a while. But it rarely happens. I used to go three to five times a week before my husband and I had our kids.

book_d111.prev_utt: You have a pretty hectic schedule, which tends to push getting to the gym to the end of the list.
book_d111.utterance: It's not that it's not a priority for me. It's just that when I'm home in the evenings and the kids get home it's all homework and dinner. There's always something else that needs my attention.

book_d112.prev_utt: Physical activity would need to be something that fits easier into your life and involve your family. If you were to start doing more activities that didn't impose on your family life, what would they be?
book_d112.utterance: Well, sometimes I take our dog for a walk. It's usually my son's responsibility, but I do it when he's too busy with homework. Sometimes we do it together, but I don't break a sweat.

book_d113.prev_utt: Since you don't break a sweat, you're wondering if it still counts.
book_d113.utterance: It's just not the same as when I work out. We're just walking around and having fun.

book_d114.prev_utt: Hi, Ted, what brings you in to see me today?
book_d114.utterance: My doctor told me to come see you. The last couple times I've seen him, he's been on me about my cholesterol. He thinks some exercise will help.

book_d115.prev_utt: Your doctor is concerned about your cholesterol and had recommended you do some physical activity to help get it down. What do you think about that plan?
book_d115.utterance: I think it's a great idea. I used to be pretty fit, but lately I've just gotten out of the habit.

book_d116.prev_utt: You're pretty excited to get started and feel the way you used to when you were in shape.
book_d116.utterance: Yeah. I'm thinking about bringing my workout clothes to work and heading over the park for a jog before I go home.

book_d117.prev_utt: You've really thought about this and you're ready to start feeling better again. When you used to be fit you felt different. How did you feel back then?
book_d117.utterance: I had more energy. I felt good about myself. Strong.

book_d118.prev_utt: You were energized and confident. You want that back.
book_d118.utterance: Yes, I want to look in the mirror and see my old self again.

book_d119.prev_utt: You want to see a person who's goal oriented and happy with a regular workout routine. Take me through your plan.
book_d119.utterance: OK. So I bring my workout clothes with me to work, change at the office, then drive over to the park. I'm thinking that an hour jog takes me around the entire loop three times. That's what I was doing before.

book_d120.prev_utt: Three loops around the park or about an hour jog is your ultimate goal. How confident are you on a scale of 0 to 10 that you'll be able to do three laps on your first day, with 0 being not confident and 10 being 100% confident?

book_d121.prev_utt: How come a 7 and not an 8 or 9?
book_d121.utterance: It's been a while since I've been out jogging. I'm a little worried that I might not make it for the whole hour. But any time is good, right?

book_d122.prev_utt: When you really think it through, you're seeing that 60 minutes sounds like a lot right off that bat, but you're willing to get out there and see what you can do. What would you think about doing an experiment this week to ease in more gradually?
book_d122.utterance: What do you have in mind?

book_d123.prev_utt: One idea is to take this week and go through the motions to make sure you've got everything set up right. Maybe just put on your clothes at work and head to the park. You could jog a little if you feel like it, but set the goal of just “showing up” this week. Then maybe next week, after you've played around with this part of the goal, you could set a certain number of min- utes or laps that line up with your current fitness level. Some of my clients have found it useful to use this fitness journal when get- ting started to write down your activity and how it feels each time you go. What do you think?
book_d123.utterance: I like this. I can do this each day this week and let you know how it goes when I come in next week.

syn_1.prev_utt: I noticed that you mentioned you’re not currently engaging in any physical activity. Can you tell me a bit more about that?
syn_1.utterance: Honestly, I just don't have the energy or time for it with everything else going on.

syn_2.prev_utt: Sometimes incorporating a bit of physical activity can really help with stress and overall well-being. How do you feel about exploring some small ways to be more active?
syn_2.utterance: I get that exercise is good for you, but I’m really not interested in it right now.

syn_3.prev_utt: What do you think are some of the challenges you might face if you tried to be more physically active?
syn_3.utterance: It just feels like too much effort and I’m already exhausted after work. I kind of don’t see how I could fit it in.

syn_4.prev_utt: Physical activity doesn’t have to be something big or time-consuming. Even a short walk can make a difference. What do you think about starting small?
syn_4.utterance: I get what you’re saying, but I’ve tried before and I never stick with it.

syn_5.prev_utt: It’s common to feel resistant to making changes, especially when life is busy. What do you think might make it easier for you to be more active?
syn_5.utterance: I'm not sure anything could make it easier. I’ve got too much on my plate already.

syn_6.prev_utt: Incorporating just a bit of physical activity each week can have significant health benefits, even if it's just a few minutes a day.
syn_6.utterance: I don't see how such a small amount could really make a difference.

syn_7.prev_utt: How do you feel about the idea of starting with something simple, like a short daily walk?
syn_7.utterance: Walking seems pointless to me. If I'm going to exercise, it should be something more intense.

syn_8.prev_utt: Many people find that even small changes in their activity level can improve their mood and energy.
syn_8.utterance: I don't think a little bit of exercise will change how tired I feel all the time.

syn_9.prev_utt: What are your thoughts on trying out a low-impact activity, like yoga or stretching, that can be done at home?
syn_9.utterance: I’ve tried yoga before and it’s just not my thing. It feels boring and slow.

syn_10.prev_utt: Finding an activity you enjoy can make being active feel less like a chore and more like fun. What do you think about that?
syn_10.utterance: I just don't enjoy any physical activities. I'd rather relax in my free time.

syn_11.prev_utt: What makes you hesitant about incorporating more physical activity into your routine?
syn_11.utterance: I already have so many things to do in a day, adding exercise feels really overwhelming.

syn_12.prev_utt: Even moderate exercise can significantly improve your overall health. What are your thoughts on this?

w6_u1.utterance: I've been worried about how much time I spend sitting. Can it really be that bad for me?

w6_u2.prev_utt: Yes, studies have shown that being inactive is linked to being overweight and obese, type 2 diabetes, some types of cancer, and even early death. Sitting for long periods can slow your metabolism, affecting your body's ability to regulate blood sugar, blood pressure, and break down body fat. Given this information about the risks of inactivity, I'm wondering what you make of it?
w6_u2.utterance: Wow, that's alarming. What can I do to counteract this?

w7_u1.utterance: I've been trying to sit less throughout the day, but it's challenging. Do you have any tips?

w7_u2.prev_utt: It's great that you're already making efforts to sit less – that shows real commitment to your health. There are several ways to reduce sitting time. For instance, you can stand on the train or bus, take the stairs instead of the elevator, and set a reminder to get up every 30 minutes.

w8_u1.utterance: I've heard that exercising regularly can prevent some health issues. Is that true?

w9_u1.utterance: Are there other benefits of being active?

w10_u1.utterance: I've been hearing a lot about the importance of being active every day. How much activity should I be aiming for each week?

w10_u2.prev_utt: According to the UK Chief Medical Officers' Physical Activity Guidelines, adults should try to be active every day and aim for at least 150 minutes of physical activity over the week. This should include a variety of activities.
w10_u2.utterance: What's the easiest way to incorporate that into my routine?

w10_u3.prev_utt: For most people, making activity part of everyday life is the simplest way to get moving. For instance, walking for health or cycling instead of using the car can be very effective. The more you do, the better, and participating in sports or exercise will make you even healthier.
w10_u3.utterance: How intense does the activity need to be?

w11_u1.utterance: I've been reading about how sitting for long periods can be really bad for your health. It's kind of worrying me.

w11_u2.prev_utt: Absolutely, you're right to be concerned. Inactivity, or what's often called sedentary behavior, is described as a "silent killer" by the Department of Health and Social Care. It includes activities like sitting or lying down for extended periods.
w11_u2.utterance: I knew it wasn't good, but I didn't realize it could be that serious. What should I do to improve this?

w11_u3.prev_utt: It's important to not only try to increase your activity levels but also to reduce the amount of time you spend sitting down throughout the day. For instance, instead of sitting to read or watch TV, you could consider standing or moving around more frequently.
w11_u3.utterance: That makes sense. I do spend a lot of time sitting, especially after work when I'm on my computer or watching TV. I guess I need to find ways to break up those periods of sitting.

w12_u1.utterance: I've been thinking about starting to exercise more regularly. I know it's important for my health, but I'm not sure where to start.

w12_u2.prev_utt: That's great to hear you're considering this. Starting to exercise is indeed beneficial for your health. Have you thought about what type of activities you enjoy or how often you'd like to exercise?
w12_u2.utterance: Well, I used to go for walks occasionally, but I haven't been very active lately. I'm not sure how much exercise I really need to do to see benefits.

w12_u3.prev_utt: It's recommended that adults aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate intensity activity each week, or 75 minutes of vigorous activity. This can be spread out over several days. It's also important to include activities that strengthen your muscles, like exercises for your legs, hips, back, abdomen, chest, shoulders, and arms, at least twice a week.
w12_u3.utterance: That sounds manageable. I think I can start with something like brisk walking and maybe some light strength exercises at home. Should I check with my doctor before starting, though? I haven't exercised regularly in a while.

w12_u4.prev_utt: Yes, that's a good idea, especially if you have any medical conditions or concerns. Your GP can help ensure the activities you choose are appropriate for your fitness level and health. Starting gradually and listening to your body as you increase your activity levels is key to avoiding injury and enjoying the benefits of exercise.
w12_u4.utterance: I'll definitely make an appointment with my GP to discuss this. I want to make sure I'm doing things right. It's encouraging to know that even a little exercise can make a difference in reducing my risk of heart disease and stroke.

w13_u1.utterance: I've been thinking about starting to exercise, but I'm not sure what activities would count as moderate intensity. Can you help me understand?

w13_u2.prev_utt: Sure, I'd be happy to help with that. Moderate intensity activities are those that raise your heart rate, make you breathe faster, and make you feel warmer, but you can still carry on a conversation without being out of breath. Examples include brisk walking, riding a bike, dancing, playing doubles tennis, and even pushing a lawn mower.
w13_u2.utterance: Oh, I see. So, activities where I can talk but not sing would be considered moderate intensity?

w13_u3.prev_utt: Exactly. That's a good way to gauge it. It's important to find activities you enjoy so you're more likely to stick with them. Have you done any of these activities before or are you thinking of trying something new?
w13_u3.utterance: I used to enjoy brisk walking before, so maybe I'll start with that. I've also heard that dancing can be fun and good exercise. Do you think that would be a good option too?

w13_u4.prev_utt: Absolutely, dancing is a great way to get moving. It not only improves your fitness but can also lift your mood. It's all about finding what suits you best. Starting with activities you enjoy will make it easier to stay motivated and make exercise a regular part of your routine
w13_u4.utterance: That makes sense. I think I'll try incorporating brisk walks and maybe some dancing into my week. It's reassuring to know that I don't have to do intense workouts to start seeing the benefits.

w14_u1.utterance: I've been thinking about stepping up my exercise routine. What exactly counts as vigorous intensity activity?

w14_u2.prev_utt: Vigorous intensity activities are those that make you breathe hard and fast. If you're working at this level, you'll find it difficult to say more than a few words without pausing for breath. Examples include running, swimming, cycling fast or uphill, playing sports like football or rugby, skipping, aerobics, and martial arts.
w14_u2.utterance: Ah, I see. So these activities really get your heart pumping?

w14_u3.prev_utt: Exactly. They require more effort and can help improve your cardiovascular fitness and stamina. It's recommended that adults aim for at least 75 minutes of vigorous intensity activity each week to achieve similar health benefits to 150 minutes of moderate intensity activity.
w14_u3.utterance: Got it. Are there any moderate activities that can become vigorous if I put in more effort?

w14_u4.prev_utt: Many activities can transition from moderate to vigorous intensity depending on your effort level. For instance, brisk walking can become vigorous if you walk uphill or increase your pace significantly. Similarly, cycling can become vigorous if you ride faster or tackle hilly terrain. Would you like to explore how you might adjust some of your current activities to increase their intensity?
w14_u4.utterance: That makes sense. I think I'll start incorporating some of these vigorous activities into my routine, like running or maybe trying out a martial arts class. It sounds like they can really boost my fitness.

w15_u1.utterance: I've heard that strength exercises are important for overall fitness. What exactly counts as a strength exercise?

w15_u2.prev_utt: Strength exercises are activities that make your muscles work harder than usual. They help to increase muscle strength, size, power, and endurance. These activities typically involve using your body weight or working against a resistance.
w15_u2.utterance: So, does that mean lifting weights is the only way to do strength exercises?

w15_u3.prev_utt: Not necessarily. While lifting weights is one way to strengthen muscles, there are many other effective exercises. You can also use resistance bands, engage in heavy gardening like digging and shoveling, climb stairs or hills, cycle, dance, do push-ups, sit-ups, squats, or even practice yoga.
w15_u3.utterance: That's good to know. How often should I be doing these strength exercises?

w15_u4.prev_utt: It's recommended to do muscle-strengthening activities at least 2 sessions or more per week. This helps to maintain and improve your muscle strength and overall fitness.
w15_u4.utterance: I see. I think I can incorporate some of these exercises into my routine, like using resistance bands or doing squats. They sound like they can really benefit my muscles.

w15_u5.prev_utt: Absolutely. Adding these exercises can enhance your strength and support your overall physical health. It's important to start with exercises that match your current fitness level and gradually increase the intensity as you become more comfortable.
w15_u5.utterance: That makes sense. I'll give these exercises a try and see how they work for me. Thanks for explaining everything!

w16_u1.utterance: I've been noticing that my balance isn't as good as it used to be, especially as I've gotten older. Are there exercises that can help improve my leg strength and balance?

w16_u2.prev_utt: You're asking about exercises for leg strength, balance, and coordination. There are indeed exercises specifically designed to improve these aspects, which are crucial for maintaining stability and preventing falls as we age.
w16_u2.utterance: That's exactly what I'm looking for. What kind of exercises are we talking about?

w16_u3.prev_utt: There are several options. Activities like tai chi, yoga, and dance are excellent for enhancing leg strength and improving balance. Even everyday activities such as walking up stairs or hiking can contribute to strengthening your legs.
w16_u3.utterance: Those sound like activities I could enjoy. Do I need any special equipment to do these exercises?

w16_u4.prev_utt: Not necessarily. For tai chi and yoga, you might benefit from a comfortable mat or a quiet space. Dance can be done with music in the comfort of your own home or at a dance class. Walking up stairs and hiking only require comfortable clothing and appropriate footwear.
w16_u4.utterance: How often should I do these exercises to see improvements in my leg strength and balance?

w17_u1.utterance: I've been feeling quite stiff lately, especially in the mornings. I'm interested in exercises that can help improve my flexibility.

w17_u2.prev_utt: Your focus on improving flexibility shows you're taking a comprehensive approach to your fitness. Flexibility exercises can really help with reducing stiffness and improving your ability to move comfortably.
w17_u2.utterance: What kind of exercises would you recommend for improving flexibility?

w17_u3.prev_utt: There are several effective flexibility exercises you can try. Stretching is a simple and effective way to increase flexibility. Yoga, tai chi, and pilates are also excellent options that focus on improving joint mobility and flexibility. Would you like to explore which of these options might work best for you and your schedule?
w17_u3.utterance: I've heard about yoga and pilates but I'm not sure which one would be better for me. Can you explain the difference?

w17_u4.prev_utt: Yoga involves holding poses that focus on stretching and strengthening various muscle groups, while also emphasizing breath control and relaxation. Pilates, on the other hand, focuses on core strength, flexibility, and body awareness through controlled movements. Both can be beneficial for improving flexibility, so it often comes down to personal preference and what feels best for your body.
w17_u4.utterance: That makes sense. How often should I do these exercises to see improvements in my flexibility?

w18_u1.utterance: I've been thinking about incorporating more strength and flexibility exercises into my routine, but I'm not sure about the benefits. Can you tell me more about why they're important?

w18_u2.prev_utt: Strengthening activities are really beneficial for maintaining your ability to do everyday tasks as you age. They help slow down the loss of muscle and bone mass that naturally occurs with getting older, which can make it easier to stay active and independent longer. Is there any aspect of strengthening training you'd particularly like to focus on? We could tailor our discussion around that.
w18_u2.utterance: What about flexibility exercises? How can they help?

w18_u3.prev_utt: Flexibility exercises are great for improving your posture, reducing aches and pains, and lowering your risk of injury. When your muscles and joints are more flexible, you can move more freely and with less discomfort during daily activities.
w18_u3.utterance: I see. So, would improving my flexibility also help with things like bending, reaching, and moving around easier?

w18_u4.prev_utt: Absolutely. Good flexibility makes it easier to perform everyday tasks like bending down to pick something up or reaching to grab an item from a shelf. It enhances your range of motion, making these movements smoother and less strained.
w18_u4.utterance: How often should I be doing these exercises to see these benefits?

w19_u1.utterance: I'm trying to figure out how much and what kinds of physical activity I need. Can you help me with that?

w19_u2.prev_utt: The key is to remember that some physical activity is better than none, so starting slowly and building up is a great approach.
w19_u2.utterance: What should I aim for as a healthy adult?

w19_u3.prev_utt: The Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans recommend incorporating both aerobic and strengthening activities into your routine. This means activities that get your heart rate up and those that build muscle strength.

w20_u1.utterance: I'm trying to figure out how much exercise I should be doing each week. Any guidelines?

w20_u2.prev_utt: Yes, aiming for at least 150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity aerobic activity is a good goal.

w20_u3.prev_utt: Activities like brisk walking, jogging, dancing, biking, and swimming are great examples. These should make your heart beat faster and cause you to breathe harder.

w27_u1.utterance: I've been struggling to stay motivated and interested in working out. It just feels like such a chore. Any ideas on how I can overcome this?

w27_u3.prev_utt: It might help to try a new activity, like dancing or water aerobics. Finding something you genuinely enjoy can make a big difference. You can also make it social by involving family and friends. Physical activity can be a fun way to spend quality time together.

w28_u3.prev_utt: For rainy days, a good rain jacket can keep you dry. In hot weather, a sun hat and sunscreen are essential, and for cold days, layering with winter clothes can help. These can make a big difference in your comfort and motivation to stick to your plans. I'm curious to hear your thoughts on this - what strategies have you already tried or considered for dealing with different weather conditions?

w29_u1.utterance: How can I overcome physical activity roadblocks? I'm afraid it will cost too much.

w29_u2.prev_utt: Getting physical activity doesn’t have to cost a lot of money. Have you checked out your local recreation or community center? They often cost less than other gyms or fitness centers, and you can pay for the months or classes you want instead of committing to a whole year.

w32_u1.utterance: I've been trying to stay motivated with my new exercise routine, but it's hard to keep going sometimes. Any tips on how I can stay motivated?

These kinds of rewards can make the process more enjoyable and encourage you to keep going.
w32_u3.utterance: I like the idea of trying new recipes with friends. It sounds fun and social. Maybe I could also look into a fitness class nearby.

w33_u1.utterance: I've been trying to be more active, but I’m not sure if it’s really worth all the effort. What are the actual benefits of physical activity?

w33_u2.prev_utt: Experts suggest that you should move more and sit less throughout the day. Even a small amount of physical activity is better than none and can bring immediate benefits. For example, being physically active can boost your mood, sharpen your focus, reduce stress, and improve your sleep.

w33_u3.prev_utt: Over time, regular physical activity can significantly improve your health. It can help prevent heart disease and stroke, control your blood pressure, and lower your risk of diseases like type 2 diabetes and some cancers. Studies also suggest that staying active can help you live a longer, healthier life.
w33_u3.utterance: Wow, I didn’t realize it had so many benefits. I guess I should try to sit less and move more each day.

w34_u1.utterance: I've been reading about different types of physical activity, but I'm a bit confused. What kinds of activities should I focus on?

w34_u2.prev_utt: That's a good question. Experts recommend two main types of physical activities: aerobic and muscle-strengthening activities.
w34_u2.utterance: Can you explain what aerobic activities are?

w34_u3.prev_utt: Sure. Aerobic activities, also known as endurance or cardio activities, involve using your large muscle groups like your chest, legs, and back. These activities help to speed up your heart rate and breathing. Examples include walking, running, cycling, and swimming.

w34_u4.prev_utt: Muscle-strengthening activities, or strength training, involve working your muscles by making you push or pull against some form of resistance. This can be done using hand-held weights, an exercise bar, exercise bands, or even everyday items like soup cans. Exercises like push-ups, squats, and lifting weights are good examples.
w34_u4.utterance: So, I need to include both types in my routine?

w35_u1.utterance: I've been wondering about how much physical activity I actually need to stay healthy. Can you give me some guidelines?

w35_u2.prev_utt: Experts recommend aiming for at least 150 minutes a week, which is 2 ½ hours, of moderate-intensity aerobic activity. You can spread this activity throughout the week in a way that works best for you.
w35_u2.utterance: So, I don't have to do it all at once?

w35_u3.prev_utt: Correct. You can spread your activity across at least 3 days a week. This approach not only improves your health but also reduces the risk of injury and prevents you from getting too tired.
w35_u3.utterance: What if I want to do more than that?

w35_u4.prev_utt: If you increase your aerobic activity to 300 minutes a week, you may lower your risk for heart disease and type 2 diabetes even further. Doing more than 300 minutes a week of moderate-intensity aerobic activity could also reduce your risk for several cancers.

w36_u1.utterance: I want to start being more active, but I'm not sure where to begin. What should I do?

w36_u2.prev_utt: That's a great decision! You don't have to be an athlete to benefit from regular physical activity. Even modest amounts can improve your health. If you've been inactive for a while, starting with easier activities is a good approach.

w39_u1.utterance: I’ve been thinking about ways to add more movement to my daily life, but I’m not sure where to start. Any suggestions?

w39_u2.prev_utt: There are several simple ways to add more physical activity to your routine. For instance, you can choose parking spots that are farther away from your destination to get in some extra steps. Just make sure the areas are safe and well lit.
w39_u2.utterance: What about when the weather is bad?

w39_u3.prev_utt: On those days, try walking around inside a shopping mall or another large building. It’s a great way to stay active without worrying about the weather. You're free to experiment with different approaches and see what works best for you.

w39_u6.prev_utt: Take regular breaks from sitting at the computer or TV. You could also start a walking or active group where you work, live, or worship. Having a buddy can help keep you focused and make the activity more enjoyable.
w39_u6.utterance: I like the idea of having a buddy. My schedule is pretty tight though. Any tips for short bursts of activity?

w39_u7.prev_utt: Definitely! If your time is limited, try doing 10 minutes of exercise at a time and spread these bursts throughout the day. Every little bit counts! Ultimately, you're the one who will be implementing these changes, so it's important that you're comfortable with them.
